awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Adsorption and Photochemical Transformations of Arsenic and Selenium Species by Natural Organic Matter-Coated Magnetic Nano-sized Iron Oxide Particles
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is supported jointly by the Chemistry Division's Environmental Chemical Sciences Program and the Environmental Engineering Program in the Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems. The collaborative study involves Professors Kevin E. O'Shea and Yong Cai from Florida International University and Professor Dionysios D. Dionysiou from University of Cincinnati. Together with their students, the faculty members seek to develop an environmentally-friendly approach to purifying water. Water contamination by highly toxic arsenic (As) and selenium (Se) is a serious threat to the environment.  This has affected the health of hundreds of millions of humans globally. The approach is to coat magnetic iron oxide nanoparticles with natural organic matter (NOM). The coated nanoparticles can strongly bind arsenic and selenium and can convert them to less toxic forms upon solar irradiation. The magnetic nanoparticles carrying the arsenic and selenium are later removed from the contaminated water with a magnet. Overall, the research activities are expected to strengthen co-operation among the local community, educational institutes, and investigators. The
broader societal impacts of this research include enhancing sustainable development. The knowledge obtained from these studies guides the development of new water treatment methodologies using environmentally-friendly materials. Application of these insights may accelerate the implementation of related technologies in addressing environmental problems, as well as advance the understanding of the interaction of natural organic matter and metals to determine their fate, transport and bioavailability.  The research plan emphasizes participation of persons from underrepresented groups. It also includes a high school outreach program with local schools to educate the students on water quality and water contamination issues.

The project seeks to develop a fundamental understanding of the molecular interactions of As and Se species with fractionated NOM and the subsequent NOM-photosensitized redox transformations of As and Se.  Specific trapping or quenching agents are used to study the roles of individual reactive oxygen species, electron transfer and energy transfer processes in the NOM photosensitized transformations. These fundamental studies guide the selection of the most promising NOM fractions for grafting onto the surface of different sized magnetic iron oxide nanoparticles for the process of interest. The research is expected to aid in the development of strategies for optimizing removal and conversion of toxic metals.  Such a process is is critical to water reuse and treatment.

por.por_cntn:
Performing adsorption studies using natural organic matter (NOM) coated magnetite nanoparticles (NOM-MNP) in aqueous media for the removal of selenium (Se) and arsenic (As) while investigating the fundamental interactions of selenium (Se) species with natural organic matter (NOM) is the main objective of this collaborative project between researchers from Florida International University (FIU) and University of Cincinnati (UC). The primary motivation for this project is the presence of the naturally occurring contaminants As and Se, which leach from rocks and minerals into groundwater, and the development of a novel, low cost, efficient, and sustainable materials for the removal of both contaminants.

While the Principal Investigators (PIs) at FIU focuses on exploiting HA coated magnetic materials to removal various contaminants, our study at University of Cincinnati is centered on characterizing the complex structure of NOM and its reaction mechanism with targeted metalloid, selenium to be more specific. To begin with, NOM fractionation was carried out using two different methods. The first one was based on conventional XAD-4 and XAD-8 resins in column separation processes. The second approach was a molecular weight (MW) fractionation utilizing ultrafiltration method. Following NOM fractionation, fundamental studies to investigate the interaction between humic acids (HA)/ fulvic acids (FA) and selenium species were investigated by tracking both macroscopic properties and molecular-level properties changes. Macroscopic properties were probed by total organic carbon (TOC), UV-vis spectroscopy, and excitation emission matrix (EEM) analyses. Molecular-level properties were characterized by Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR) to study the functional group shifts, high-resolution Orbitrap mass spectroscopy (Orbitrap MS) to observe changes to chemical formulae, and liquid chromatography coupled with inductively coupled plasma mass spectroscopy (LC-ICP-MS) to analyze the amount of selenate (Se(VI)) and selenite (Se(IV)) species.

The PI and collaborators conducted a variety of activities to enhance education on contaminants of concern such as Se and As, and the role of NOM: (i) offering collaborative research opportunities to student researchers including summer interns, (ii) rigorous and systematic cross-disciplinary training of involved students, (iii) broad dissemination of results through class materials, conference presentations, group meetings, and meetings with collaborators, and (iv) strengthening of research collaboration, including with several research facilities and other departments. This work can also have strong societal impacts. Selenium is an essential trace element for both human and animals while also a contaminant of emerging concern. Raising the awareness of selenium contamination holds paramount importance as raising awareness for other commonly known heavy metal contamination. We believe that a comprehensive characterization of NOM and its mechanistic interaction with selenium species provided in this study will enable us to have a deeper understanding of the interaction between these two constituents broadly present in many environmental systems. The outcomes of this study have both scientific and practical benefits regarding selenium risk assessment and treatment.

This work makes significant contribution to the field because according to literature review, so far there is no clear understanding regarding the interactions between the supramolecular structure of NOM and selenium species. This work comprehensively tracked and analyzed bulk and molecular level properties changes for each HA/FA fractions in the presence of selenium species. More specifically, the spectroscopic properties, functional group change, and compound classes with respect to every MW fraction were analyzed and investigated. The obtained information can contribute substantially to filling the gaps for NOM interactions with selenium species and hopefully invoke future studies in similar directions involving other commonly found metalloids.
